# Week 7: 15–21 December 2025

## Tuesday

I had some time left this week, so I started looking deeper into **samplers** and how I could add **vocals** into the sessions I’m working on. I mainly focused on vocals that would fit well in a **trance or techno** context.

One of my first thoughts was **Rosalía’s newer work**, where she combines hard, modern beats with operatic vocals. That contrast really stuck with me and feels very relevant to the direction I’m exploring with FE_VER.

Because Strudel works with GitHub-based samplers, I knew I had two options:
- Download and prepare external vocal samples
- Or record my own vocals (since I know how to sing)

While searching for inspiration, I came across this **ancient Arabic / Middle Eastern acapella vocalist**. The raw, expressive quality of the voice immediately stood out to me, and I think it could work beautifully in a techno or trance context; especially when chopped, filtered, or stretched.

Imagine a stutter on this vocal with a bass kick.

<iframe width="80%" height="400"
src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/oBGFueJtOzw"
title="Middle Eastern Acapella Vocal Inspiration"
frameborder="0"
allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture"
allowfullscreen></iframe>

I also found another vocal performance that reinforced this idea of using **traditional or expressive vocals** in a modern electronic setting.

<iframe width="80%" height="400"
src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/B_D3dCSylCg"
title="Vocal Inspiration"
frameborder="0"
allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture"
allowfullscreen></iframe>

---

## Wednesday

On Wednesday, I decided to simplify my workflow. Instead of constantly changing everything, I worked with a **fixed base**:  
- a preset **post-gain structure**
- a fixed **beat selection**
- and a stable **note framework**

I noticed that starting from a solid foundation makes it much easier to experiment freely with sound design, melodies, and textures without losing direction.

### Starter Set (Base Rhythm & Structure)

This set functions as a **reliable rhythmic backbone** that I can return to whenever I want to test new ideas quickly.

---

### Small Melody Experiment

From that same base, I added a simple melodic layer to see how minimal melodic movement could interact with the drums.

<iframe
  src="https://strudel.cc/#CnNldENwcygxNDAvNjAvNCkKc2FtcGxlcygnZ2l0aHViOnRpZGFsY3ljbGVzL2RpcnQtc2FtcGxlcycpCgoKY29uc3QgU3RydWN0dXJlcyA9IFsKICAie359IiwKICAieCo0IiwKICAie3ggfiE2IHggfiB%2BIHggfiEzIHggfn0lMTYiLAogICJ7eCB%2BITMgeCB%2BITMgeCB%2BITIgeCB%2BITIgeCB%2BfSUxNiIsCiAgInt4IH4hOSB4IH4hNSB4IH4geCB%2BITcgeCB%2BITMgPCB%2BIHggPiB%2BfSUxNiIsCiAgInt%2BITMgeCB%2BITMgeCB%2BITMgeCB%%%2BITIgeCExMCB%"
  width="100%"
  height="400"
  frameborder="0">
</iframe>

Keeping the melody restrained helped me focus more on **texture**, **rhythm**, and **energy flow** rather than complexity.

---

This week was smaller, but important. It helped me realise how powerful **vocals**, **sampling**, and **working from a fixed base** can be when building longer live-coded performances.
